On Mon, 07 Jun 2004 18:57:20 -0000, Kenneth Stanley
<kstanley@...> wrote:
> Ah, we may have hit on a reason for some of our disagreements!  The
> add_connection mutation rate is the probability that an *individual
> genome* might have a single connection added.  In other words, in a
> population of 100 individuals and a 0.02 rate, you would expect to
> get on average 2 new connections over the entire population in a
> single generation.
> 
> In addition, it is also true that only one add connection mutation
> can happen to a single individual in a generation.

Wow.  Okay.

We made the assumption that NEAT worked similiarly to biological
mutations.  Because what you are describing is definitely *not* the
way biological mutations work, or what "mutation rates" mean.  In
biology, the mutation rate refers to the frequency of mutations per
*gene* per unit of time.  And though I'm not extremely familiar with
genetic programming, my understanding was that mutation rates referred
to the probability of a given binary bit position being flipped.

It does not seem intuitive to assume that mutation rates are referring
to individuals, rather than genes or smaller units.

> It seems to me that your interpetation was that the mutation rate is
> on a "per empty slot" basis.  That's radically different than my
> NEAT implementation...interesting though that that works at all...is
> that how ANJI has been working?

Yeah.  And it works.

It seems straightforward to say that there are 10,000 potential
locations for a structural mutation, so a given rate (e.g., 0.01)
describes the probability for a mutation occurring at that location. 
Basically, you're describing the rate at which a given individual can
be mutated, with exclusion (so a given chromosome cannot have more
than one type of mutation...can a single chromosome have both an add
connection and add node mutation in the same generation?).

It also seems confusing that the rates for mutating connection weights
work one way (occurring with a given probability based on the number
of locations), while the structural mutation rates define something
else entirely.

Derek
